conclusion: Analyze forces to find mass ratio of A and C balls.
Forces include gravitational forces on balls and tension in wires.
Net force on each ball must be zero due to equilibrium.
Ball B has no pressure on bowl wall, normal force is zero.
Tension in wire balances component of weight of ball B.
Angle between wire and vertical is θ = 30°.
Vertical component of tension balances weight of ball B: T cos(30°) = m_B g.
Horizontal component of tension is T sin(30°).
Ball C is connected to ball B and subject to its own weight.
Tension in wire balances weight of ball C: T = m_C g.
Relate tensions: T cos(30°) = m_B g and T = m_C g.
Simplify to m_C cos(30°) = m_B.
m_C √3/2 = m_B, therefore m_B = √3/2 m_C.
Ball A is connected to ball B by another wire.
Tension in wire connecting A and B balances weight of ball A: T' = m_A g.
T' is same as T in wire connecting B and C due to equilibrium.
Relate masses: T = m_C g, therefore m_A g = m_C g.
Simplify to m_A = m_C.
Mass ratio of ball A to ball C is 1.
